source: Learn more in the app.

sections.doc_:
## Introduction

[amp-app-banner](/amp-dev/documentation/components/reference/amp-app-banner-v0.1.md) provides a minimal UI for a cross-platform, fixed-position banner showing a call-to-action to install an app. In particular, `amp-app-banner` works inside an AMP viewer such as the Top Stories carousel in Google Search. Outside of the AMP viewer, the native app banners will be displayed instead of `amp-app-banner` in Safari on iOS and in Chrome on Android.
sections.cachedMarkedDoc:
Introduction

amp-app-banner provides a minimal UI for a cross-platform, fixed-position banner showing a call-to-action to install an app. In particular, amp-app-banner works inside an AMP viewer such as the Top Stories carousel in Google Search. Outside of the AMP viewer, the native app banners will be displayed instead of amp-app-banner in Safari on iOS and in Chrome on Android.
sections.normalizedDoc_:
## Introduction

[amp-app-banner](/amp-dev/documentation/components/reference/amp-app-banner-v0.1.md) provides a minimal UI for a cross-platform, fixed-position banner showing a call-to-action to install an app. In particular, `amp-app-banner` works inside an AMP viewer such as the Top Stories carousel in Google Search. Outside of the AMP viewer, the native app banners will be displayed instead of `amp-app-banner` in Safari on iOS and in Chrome on Android.

sections.doc_: Declare the iOS app in the [meta data](https://developer.apple.com/library/content/documentation/AppleApplications/Reference/SafariWebContent/PromotingAppswithAppBanners/PromotingAppswithAppBanners.html). This enables Safari's build-in app install banner as well.
sections.normalizedDoc_: Declare the iOS app in the [meta data](https://developer.apple.com/library/content/documentation/AppleApplications/Reference/SafariWebContent/PromotingAppswithAppBanners/PromotingAppswithAppBanners.html). This enables Safari's build-in app install banner as well.

sections.doc_: Android apps need to be declared in the [web app manifest](/amp-app-banner-manifest.json). This will also enable the [native app install banner](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2015/03/increasing-engagement-with-app-install-banners-in-chrome-for-android#native) in Chrome on Android.
sections.normalizedDoc_: Android apps need to be declared in the [web app manifest](/amp-app-banner-manifest.json). This will also enable the [native app install banner](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2015/03/increasing-engagement-with-app-install-banners-in-chrome-for-android#native) in Chrome on Android.

sections.doc_: Deep links into your apps are calculated based on your AMP's canonical link. Here we link to an article on Medium as we don't have a native AMP by Example app.
sections.normalizedDoc_: Deep links into your apps are calculated based on your AMP's canonical link. Here we link to an article on Medium as we don't have a native AMP by Example app.

sections.code:
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,minimum-scale=1,initial-scale=1">
<style amp-boilerplate>body{-webkit-animation:-amp-start 8s steps(1,end) 0s 1 normal both;-moz-animation:-amp-start 8s steps(1,end) 0s 1 normal both;-ms-animation:-amp-start 8s steps(1,end) 0s 1 normal both;animation:-amp-start 8s steps(1,end) 0s 1 normal both}@-webkit-keyframes -amp-start{from{visibility:hidden}to{visibility:visible}}@-moz-keyframes -amp-start{from{visibility:hidden}to{visibility:visible}}@-ms-keyframes -amp-start{from{visibility:hidden}to{visibility:visible}}@-o-keyframes -amp-start{from{visibility:hidden}to{visibility:visible}}@keyframes -amp-start{from{visibility:hidden}to{visibility:visible}}</style><noscript><style amp-boilerplate>body{-webkit-animation:none;-moz-animation:none;-ms-animation:none;animation:none}</style></noscript>

<style amp-custom>
:root {
--space-1: .5rem;  /* 8px */
}
#my-app-banner {
position: fixed;
bottom: 0;
display: flex;
width: 100%;
justify-content: center;
align-items: center;
padding: var(--space-1);
}
#my-app-banner .banner-text {
flex: 1;
margin: 0 var(--space-1);
}
#my-app-banner button {
border: none;
background: none;
-webkit-appearance: none;
}
</style>
</head>
<body>

sections.doc_:
## Basic usage

The `amp-app-banner` can be fully customized by the developer as long as the height doesn't exceed 100px.  One required UI element is a button with the attribute `[open-button]`, which triggers the app install, or opens the deep-link if the app is already installed.
sections.code: Learn more in the app.
sections.normalizedDoc_:
## Basic usage

The `amp-app-banner` can be fully customized by the developer as long as the height doesn't exceed 100px.  One required UI element is a button with the attribute `[open-button]`, which triggers the app install, or opens the deep-link if the app is already installed.

sections.doc_:
## Demo

The custom app banner shows up in AMP Viewers. The banner action opens the document's canonical URL as deep-link inside the app:

[sourcecode:html]
<amp-video width="1920" height="1080"
  src="/video/amp-app-banner-android-app-installed.mp4"
           layout="responsive"
           controls>
</amp-video>
[/sourcecode]

...and if the app is not installed, the banner action shows the app in the Play Store / App Store:

[sourcecode:html]
<amp-video width="1920" height="1080"
  src="/video/amp-app-banner-android-app-not-installed.mp4"
           layout="responsive"
           controls>
</amp-video>
[/sourcecode]
## Testing

The `amp-app-banner` will only show in browsers that don't provide their own app install banner. This means Chrome on Android or Safari on iOS will not show the `amp-app-banner,` but the native install banner. For testing `amp-app-banner` you can open this page:

* **On a mobile device:** in browser without native install banner, e.g. [Firefox](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=org.mozilla.firefox&hl=en_GB) on Android or [Chrome](https://itunes.apple.com/gb/app/chrome-web-browser-by-google/id535886823?mt=8) on iOS.
* **On Desktop:** in [mobile device emulation mode](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/chrome-devtools/device-mode/) append `#webview=1` to the [page URL](http://localhost:8080/components/amp-app-banner/#webview=1). The other option is to use a custom user agent in mobile emulation mode, for example: `Mozilla/5.0 (iPhone; CPU iPhone OS 9_1 like Mac OS X) AppleWebKit/601.1.46 (KHTML, like Gecko) CriOS/51.000.21 Mobile/13B143 Safari/601.1`
sections.normalizedDoc_:
## Demo

The custom app banner shows up in AMP Viewers. The banner action opens the document's canonical URL as deep-link inside the app:

```html
<amp-video width="1920" height="1080"
  src="/video/amp-app-banner-android-app-installed.mp4"
           layout="responsive"
           controls>
</amp-video>
```

...and if the app is not installed, the banner action shows the app in the Play Store / App Store:

```html
<amp-video width="1920" height="1080"
  src="/video/amp-app-banner-android-app-not-installed.mp4"
           layout="responsive"
           controls>
</amp-video>
```
## Testing

The `amp-app-banner` will only show in browsers that don't provide their own app install banner. This means Chrome on Android or Safari on iOS will not show the `amp-app-banner,` but the native install banner. For testing `amp-app-banner` you can open this page:

* **On a mobile device:** in browser without native install banner, e.g. [Firefox](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=org.mozilla.firefox&hl=en_GB) on Android or [Chrome](https://itunes.apple.com/gb/app/chrome-web-browser-by-google/id535886823?mt=8) on iOS.
* **On Desktop:** in [mobile device emulation mode](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/chrome-devtools/device-mode/) append `#webview=1` to the [page URL](http://localhost:8080/components/amp-app-banner/#webview=1). The other option is to use a custom user agent in mobile emulation mode, for example: `Mozilla/5.0 (iPhone; CPU iPhone OS 9_1 like Mac OS X) AppleWebKit/601.1.46 (KHTML, like Gecko) CriOS/51.000.21 Mobile/13B143 Safari/601.1`

<meta charset="utf-8">
  <title>amp-app-banner</title>
  <script async src="https://cdn.ampproject.org/v0.js"></script>
  <script async custom-element="amp-app-banner" src="https://cdn.ampproject.org/v0/amp-app-banner-0.1.js"></script>
  <script async custom-element="amp-video" src="https://cdn.ampproject.org/v0/amp-video-0.1.js"></script>
  <meta name="apple-itunes-app" content="app-id=828256236, app-argument=medium://p/9ea61abf530f">
  <link rel="manifest" href="/amp-app-banner-manifest.json">
  <link rel="canonical" href="http://localhost:8080/documentation/examples/components/amp-app-banner/index.html">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,minimum-scale=1,initial-scale=1">
  <style amp-boilerplate>body{-webkit-animation:-amp-start 8s steps(1,end) 0s 1 normal both;-moz-animation:-amp-start 8s steps(1,end) 0s 1 normal both;-ms-animation:-amp-start 8s steps(1,end) 0s 1 normal both;animation:-amp-start 8s steps(1,end) 0s 1 normal both}@-webkit-keyframes -amp-start{from{visibility:hidden}to{visibility:visible}}@-moz-keyframes -amp-start{from{visibility:hidden}to{visibility:visible}}@-ms-keyframes -amp-start{from{visibility:hidden}to{visibility:visible}}@-o-keyframes -amp-start{from{visibility:hidden}to{visibility:visible}}@keyframes -amp-start{from{visibility:hidden}to{visibility:visible}}</style><noscript><style amp-boilerplate>body{-webkit-animation:none;-moz-animation:none;-ms-animation:none;animation:none}</style></noscript>
document.title: amp-app-banner

metadata.comment: Don't install serviceworker as canonical domain is different than serviceworker domain
